item.description:
From the publisher:

Magic, fun and adventure await as you travel along the Yellow Brick Road to see the Wizard of Oz! Help the Scarecrow get his brain, the Tin Woodsman find his heart, the Cowardly Lion gather courage and Dorothy find her way back home. Call on Toto to help move you along but beware of the Wicked Witch who is waiting to spoil your plans and send you back to Start! So, click your heels, roll the die and let the adventure begin! Comes in a colorful fun box.

item.description:
Subtitled "Classic Seafaring Action" Pirate Attack is a game based on the public domain Battleship.

It comes with a suitable pirate themed game board and pieces including pirate ships with sails that are knocked off when hit. The game differs from the classic game by adding two special weapons. Cannonballs are the standard shots, but players also have the limited options to use "Shrapnel" or a "Telescope Targeting"

item.description: A game similar to Operation where players attempt to retrieve stolen treasures from a giant without waking him up by using a pair of tweezers and not touching the edges where the treasure is stored. Ages 6 and up.

EMS Challenge - the game that challenges emergency medical professionals! EMS Challenge is a take on the trivia board game intended to be an enjoyable method of reviewing information pertaining to professionals in the pre-hospital care field.

On your turn you must answer a trivia question from one of four categories: definitions, medical terminology, anatomy and physiology, or miscellaneous. A correct answer entitles you to roll the die and advance.

Special squares mix up play slightly including "pick your category" spaces, "player to the right picks your category" spaces, and time trials which are small tasks with a time limit (i.e. roll a 1 in five seconds) and give small rewards (advance one space)

The game contains 400 question cards, 4 tokens, a die, a game board, and instructions.

From publisher:

"Maximilian! Rules. Fast Play rules for the High Renaissance. Contains 48 pages, with card cover and play sheet. Has all rules required, plus 30 army lists. Please see the Maximilian Army packs for complete starter armies."

The system shares basing and many mechanics with the DBx series.

Square Play is an abstract strategy game played on a board of inset squares. Each player takes turns placing one of seven tokens in the hope of creating a square with four tokens. If they fail in that effort, players take turns moving a token to create either a square with four tokens or a straight line with three, whereupon they can remove an opponent's token.

Play continues until either a square is formed or until a player is eliminated due to having only 2 tokens left on the board.

A humorous game published in InQuest #150, cover date October 2007. Players choose their team, which is really their pawn, all of which are based on classic gaming icons; example HeroKlutz referring to HeroClix. The player then works to overcome various challenges at the carnival, defeat other players, and collect three pieces that will make up the "Ultimate Weapon," which leads to victory.

This game simulates an Italian soccer tournament. The players play each other moving their soccer team markers on the board spaces using a spinner. The spaces of the board represent events occurring in a typical soccer game that give the chance to score a goal: goal kicks, corner kicks, penalties, and so on. The game box includes cards and markers of the 30 best Italian soccer teams of the '70s, goal markers and a goalkeeper figure to be used on penalty kicks.

As the year 2015 came to a close it was clear the world was in a new trend. Instead of fighting wars with their own conventional forces, nations found it easier to pass the burden of conflict along to private contractors. They could be expensive, but a mercenary force was less politically liable than a country and more expendable. The best survived, and went on to glory and profit. The most famous and sought after are the mercenary pilots.

The leader of a Mercenary Air Squadron has many responsibilities. The fortunes of his or her firm depend on taking the right jobs for his pilots, outfitting with the right equipment, and keeping those birds flying. One month a mercenary squadron could be flying combat operations over the Pacific Ocean for Japan, and turn around and join the highest bidder against their former employer. Nothing is personal, except for rivalries amongst mercenary squadrons, which tend to lead to heated exchanges beyond that specified in a contract. Your prestige and fortune are at stake. Pilots, man your planes and your pocketbooks!

Expanded by:

 Mercenary Air Squadron World War II: Mediterranean Theater of Operations

link.value: Mercenary Air Squadron World War II: Mediterranean Theater of Operations

item.description:
The 4th wargame using the En Pointe Toujours (EPT) company-scale tactical combat game system. The scenarios cover conflict in France and Belgium in 1940.

The EPT II and EPT III scenarios can use the rules of EPT IV.

Contents:
- 4 A4 29 x 21 cm geomorphic maps (they can be arranged in different ways to form different terrain)
- about 200 counters to be cut and mounted
- rules in French

item.description:
A simple tactical wargame covering the battle of Anthon 1430 in France, between the Prince of Orange, ally of the Burgundians, and Bernard de Saluces, allied to the King of France.

The wargame uses the Au fil de l'épée game system published in Vae Victis magazine #45, emphasizing on leaders command.

It includes:

- 25 counters to be cut out and mounted
- a one-page scenario rules (in French)

name.value: La destruction de la 106. Panzer Brigade, Lorraine 1944
La destruction de la Panzer Brigade 106

item.description:
La destruction de la Panzer Brigade 106 (Destruction of 106th Panzer Brigade) is a small introductory WWII wargame, simulating the clash in France between the 106th Panzer Brigade and the 90th US Infantry Division.

The game uses a easy movement-combat I-go-You-Go system, each turn game represents 2 hours of real time, a hex is 1 km cross, each counter is a batallion, a company or a squadron.

It is published on Vae Victis Hors-série #6 and includes:
- a 21 x 29 cm map,
- 22 counters to be cut and mounted
- a 2-pages rules in French

item.description:
Miniatures wargaming without the paperwork.

The On the Counter (OtC) system is a framework for creating miniature style wargames without the miniatures, and without the tedious record keeping. It eliminates the need for status sheets, army rosters and hit location tables by placing everything you need directly on the counter.

The OtC system lets you spend your time thinking about playing the game instead of managing it. The basic set comes with basic rules, plus counters and special rules for four different genres of combat: Mecha, Starships, World War One Dogfights and World War Two company scale combat.

The On the Counter system is released under a Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 License Creative Commons License.

The archive includes a counter template for GIMP that you can use to create your own counters. Go ahead and make your own genres, scenarios and counters.

Iowa State Fairopoloy board game is a spinoff the popular Monopoly game, produced by an advertising firm in Newton, IA in 2004. It celebrated the 150 Year Anniversary (sesquicentennial) of The Iowa State Fair.
It has the same basic game play as Monopoly; dice rolling, buying properties, trading, buying houses, paying rent, etc. It features tokens in the shapes of a cow, a Ferris wheel and a horse. Players landing on Brad and Harry's cheese curds concession can buy it for $90.

name.value: Legends of the Ancient World: The Sorcerer's Manor

item.description:
There is a new evil in the Maul. Murders and abductions are at an alarming high, and the people are powerless and scared. The evil seems to come from the sorcerer's manor, an ancient structure that predates the current civilization. However, none who have tried to burgle or collect taxes have returned.

This is a complete fantasy mini-adventure for solitaire or group play. It is suitable for one to four players, ages 12 and up. This game includes the adventure book, rules, pieces and playing board and is compatible with other role-playing systems such as GURPS (TM) and The Fantasy Trip (TM).

item.description:
Three player chess on a hexagonal board with three colors for spaces.

Also three Bishops (one per color of space for each player) and Knights that start the game in a third rank behind the main setup.

Simple card game in which players representing parodies of Anime characters on a killing spree, who compete for the most victims. Weapon cards are used to modify abilities and die rolls are added to attack and defense scores. Generally, victim cards must be attacked multiple times to be "finished off," and get to counterattack. Certain cards have special effects upon the game's rules.

Similar to:

 Stellar Slaughter: A Game of Science Fiction Horror Movie Madness

Object: Players try to win each card by looking at the photo and correctly answering a question from that card. The player who collects the most cards is the winner.

You can play all the questions or just a few. And because no game board or score pad is needed, you can play anywhere! Play at home, at parties, or while traveling.

Number of players: Two or more, individually or in teams.

Approximate Playing Time: 10 minutes to a whole evening.

Equipment: Two decks of Photo Trivia cards - 107 photos, 642 questions and answers, rules.

The Potpourri Game has something for everyone!

name.value: The Original Baseball Playing Card Game

item.description:
A card game played using the regular rules of baseball. Players draw 5 cards at a time and take turns playing cards that either aid in scoring or in making outs. Hands are replenished when cards are played.

Contents:

Baseball diamond map sheet
Custom deck of cards with scoring (red) or black (outs) that are played according to the game situation.
Laminated scoreboard 
Black crayon
Erasing cloth 
Score pad for tracking results
8 plastic baseball players (4 red & 4 blue)
Instruction sheet

From the Instructions:

The object of the game is to be the first player to get all your game pieces into the mouth, down to the Stomach, around the body and to the Finish Area (on the person's shoulder). As you are playing, the Energy Cards will teach you about Klamath Lake Blue Green Algae. Game recommended for ages 8 to adult.

Contents:

1 Tri-fold Game Board depicting the pathway of a person ingesting Algae and it's route through the body 
24 game pieces representing vitamin-like bottles
54 energy Cards

A variant of Parchesi with the intent of educating people to the benefits of eating Algae.Each space is colored and acts as a "safe" area to pawns of a matching color.

name.value: Wherry: The Elizabethan Thames River Game

item.description:
(from the rulebook explanation)

Wherry is a game of Watermanship on the Shakespearean Thames. In the merry but sometimes threatening ambiance of 16th century Elizabethan London, players of this game will re-enact the working lifestyle of a Thames Waterman (Wherryman). They will pick up passengers in their Wherries, from the various Landing Stairs situated along the riverbank and while rowing them to their destination, they will have to deal with the prevailing conditions of the tide, weather and other river hazards. They must also try to avoid colliding with other Wherries or with the Royal Barge and must give careful thought to the many chances and choices they will have during their voyaging up and down the river Thames.
From the box, "An amusing game in which players compete to make the l-o-n-g-e-s-t snake." Ages 3 and up
Monopoly clone made for the town of Broken Arrow Mississippi.

A leader secretly selects a word then players take turns guessing its letters, yet the game expands upon the familiar Hangman concept.

The leader’s word must contain the letters shown on three cards drawn from a deck containing letters of the alphabet. A player’s guess must state both a letter and the numerical position within the word. The leader will declare the guess to be “Right”, “Wrong”, or “Almost”, where the latter indicates a valid letter but not at that position.

Printed score sheets allow players to track the progress of all guesses. Individual players score a point for each “Right” guess, and get another turn. The leader scores points for all the “Wrong” and “Almost” guesses. The role of leader passes for multiple rounds.

Open ended number of players, can be executed as a party game.

From the manufacturer:

Little ones will enjoy the Flintstones Stone Age Memory Game! You don't need to be a prehistoric scientist to build your own Stone Age Television, Rock Guitar, or Baby Carriage. Each of the 12 inventions in the game is split into 4 cards. Collect them all and you can keep the invention. Play with your friends to see who can collect the most inventions, or use the special rules to play by yourself. For 1 or more players. Ages 4 - 8.

From the manufacturer:

Calling all Junior Detectives!! Using real detective gadgets, solve a new mystery every time you play The Detective Kit Game. Create a clue card and decode secret code words. Write, and reveal, hidden messages with an invisible ink pen. Search the Ski Shop, Zoo and Aquarium for clues that will verify your hunches. Follow the footprints on the trail and use your magnifying glass to compare matching thumb prints. Collect the correct clues, and then race back to the Detective's office to win the game! For 2 to 4 Players. Ages 8 and up.

Players Race to be the first one to find all three keys in a designated area and bring them back to the electronic treasure chest. The keys are hidden beforehand by an extra non-playing person. When the Chest recognizes that a player has put in all three different keys it will open and play victory music.

item.description: This is a dexterity/skill game for children involving the placement of ladybug pieces on the leaves of a palm tree. The palm tree leaves (fronds?) have various colored circles on them in rows from closest to the trunk to farthest away from the trunk. The tree leaves have some degree of movement, and if too much weight is placed on them, they will dip or bend down. Players take turn rolling a dice with various colored sides, and then placing a ladybug piece on a matching colored circle on a leaf. The goal of the game is to get rid of all your ladybugs, but if your placement causes ladybugs to fall, those pieces become yours. The game continues until one player is out of ladybugs. The leaves have different lengths and there are three sizes of ladybugs (small, medium and large), so there is some definite strategy about which ladybug gets placed where. The tree, leaves, and ladybugs are all nicely formed and painted wooden pieces.
Monkey Bowling comes with 6 3" brightly painted wooden monkeys and 1 wooden ball. A fun game for children (and adults!) Play is just what you would expect - Set 'em up, knock 'em down!

It's all good, clean fun - at least that's the intention. But you never know what might slip out when you're playing Innuendo. If someone starts talking about things that sometimes don't rise, just what are they referring to ? Yorkshire puddings? Share prices ?

Well what were you thinking of ?!

name.value: The New Game "Auctioneer" or Going! Going! Gone!

item.description: The object of this card game is to collect as many pairs as possible. The game, first published in 1916, has cards with objects on them, a gavel, and some coins. At the start of the game the cards are dealt and the coins distributed evenly. One player takes the first turn at being auctioneer. He takes up the gavel and declares an item for sale from his cards. The trick is the auctioneer can only describe the item by it's number of legs. Many different items have the same number of legs, so players have to bid on the chance that they are getting the item they need, without really knowing it. The purchaser of the card becomes the new auctioneer. As players earn pairs they set them aside and are assigned a value. When all cards are exhausted the winner is the one with the most value in pairs and in coins.

Owch is a game for two or four players based on the classic game Ludo/Parcheesi. Each player takes on the role of a construction foreman (Ollie, Wally, Holly, or Carlie), and each team of two foremen must get all of their workers to the job site to win.

Players sitting opposite from each other are partners. Partners can stack their workers to block their opponents, or play cards to impede their progress around the board.

Contains:
- Game board
- 2 dice
- 16 workers
- 25 cards
- 4 sabotage markers
- 1 booby-trap marker
- 1 dodgy curry marker
- Rule book
- Top Tips strategy card

Spanish Fury, Voyage! is a STAND ALONE game of Corsair activity in the Caribbean from 1550 to 1585. The Corsair player (or players) enters the region with ships packed with either Trade Good or troops (usually both) in hopes of turning a profit by hook or by crook. The Spanish Empire player must see that he prevents the Corsairs from succeeding (and discouraging others) while at the same time running the Caribbean efficiently so as to not lose his Vice-royalty (is that a word?).

FREE game to download here: http://perfectcaptain.50megs.com/sfvoyage.html

This isn't normal game entry, but it should be used to categorize miscellaneous miniatures games related items such as terrain, buildings, obstacles etc. used in Miniature Games.

Items in the BoardGameGeek Marketplace may refer to items listed here.

item.description:
Alte Spiele -- Games of Old -- Jeux d'Autrefois
1975 Calendar

This was a 1975 promotional calendar from printing press manufacturer Roland Offset. it contained six roll-and-move style games from the 1800s.

From the first page:
"Present-day games have contemporary goals: The imagination envisions planetary flight and the psycho tests of the psychologist are dinner table discussion. In this context, who would like to hazard his fortune on a throw of dice? Even in cases where chance is permitted, workaday personal and occupational practices persist - the neighbor is shunted aside or his property gloatingly purchased at auction...

All of this was not evident at the beginning of our rushing century. All one wanted to do at the end of the day was to relax. Television, radio, record player and cinema were unknown. The first motorists purchased their fuel at the apothecary and the operator of a magic-lantern illuminated his coloured glass slides with a kerosene lamp. The village squares were still the site of public wells, although some well-to-do people already had gaslight. Geese were allowed to graze the entire summer. Skiing was just beginning to be recognized as a sport. A race track for horses in the city was a novelty. And a locomotive engineer was admired by all the boys: 'What a man!'

Games of old reflect this world of the small adventures, where it was an event if a train derailed or even when a fowl flew its coop. Then in those days games were modern and exciting. Even for their producers..."

January/February - "The Ski Race"
March/April - "The Tramway"
May/June - "We Take The Train"
July/August - "The Goose Game"
September/October - "The Automobile Race"
November/December - "Commerce And Trade"

item.description:
This is Monopoly but based on the St. Louis Cardinals MLB baseball team.
It contains 6 pewter peices.
Published at a time When Mark Mcquire was on the team.

item.description:
On November 19th, 1941, as the sun rose over a new day in the Libyan Desert, a clock was ticking in the headquarters of the British Eighth Army. They had done the impossible and surprised Erwin Rommel, the Desert Fox, slipping nearly five hundred tanks behind his lines. The opportunity to crush the Afrika Korps lay within their grasp...

Totensonntag is the expanded 2nd Edition of Peter Bogdasarian’s Totensonntag from the award-winning Corps Command-system game. At stake: The First Battle of Sidi Rezegh, fought between the British Commonwealth’s XXX Corps and Germany’s Panzerarmee Afrika during Operation Crusader. Relive the battles, from the opening skirmishes to the hellish clash on Totensonntag, the Sunday of the Dead.

The Corps Command system is easily learned and taught, perfect for an evening’s entertainment. So choose your side and make some history!

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 day
Hex: 3 miles / 4.8 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Division

Game Inventory:
Two 11 x 17.5" full-color mapsheets
One dual-side printed countersheets (100 5/8" counters - includes 8 blanks)
One 8-page Totensonntag rules booklet
One dual-side printed Player Aid card
Two 6-sided die

Complexity: Medium-Low
Solitaire Suitability: Medium-High
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 1-3 Hours

item.description: Phonics based word game for Ages 6 and up.
Role and Move game based on the Looney Tunes Characters Sylvester and Tweety.

From the Box (all spellings and grammar are identical to the box text):

The Alaskan Gold Rush

A Game of High Adventure

Is the rousing new board game that combines the excitement of poker with the incredible adventures of the Alaskan Frontier.

In the 1890's thousands of greenhorns flooded the Port of Skagway looking for riches beyond their wildest dreams. However, charging bull moose, ferocious Grizzly bear, raging rivers, ice flows and frost bite (sic) await all those who quest for gold. Only the most experienced gold-panners emerged from the wilderness unscathed with gold in their pockets. These SOURDOUGHS were the toughest of the tough, and would literally risk an entire year's earnings on the flip of a card in a poker hand.

Would you be willing to bet everything you have on a bluff, or will you play it safe. This is a game of strategy, luck and skill, where the game dramatically changes with the personality of the players.

The easy to play game includes:

1 Board of Alaska (the game track is superimposed on a satellite picture)
1 Deck of standard playing cards
100 Silver and Gold coins (Poker Chips)
100 $1 Dollar Bills
6 Playing pieces
1 Die (d6)
27 Adventure cards (15 gold, 12 silver)
6 I.O.U. Cards (4 gold, 2 silver)
Rules

The game begins as a simple roll-and-move mechanic with various spaces giving rewards or penalties. There are also spaces that can trigger a round of poker between the players - winner take all monies bet. The players must accumulate wealth enough to buy transportation to the gold fields and then find the motherlode (Big Vein). Once there, a final hand of poker is played and the person at the mine must have $500,000 remaining after the hand.

The components are of high quality and it presents an interesting twist on a mundane night of poker.

name.value: Wine Tour: The Napa Valley Game

item.description:
From the Instruction book:

Object: Tour the Napa Valley wine country starting from San Francisco, collecting wine point cards by visiting wineries along the way. In addition, Case Cards are collected from the burgundy-colored wineries at the ends of the side roads, and a bumper sticker is collected upon landing directly on Calistoga. The first person to return to San Francisco with 500 points (or a pre-determined number), at least two case cards (which are worth points and are included in the total) and a Calistoga bumper sticker, wins the game.

Equipment:

4 Decks of city cards
1 die
4 Wooden player tokens (in the shape of wine bottles)
1 deck of case cards
Bumper Stickers
Wine Point cards
Balloon spinner

The games looks as if it were produced to advertise the wineries of the Napa Valley. Over half of the instruction booklet is filled with the names and addresses of wineries that supported the game. Not much decision making here, even the intersections on the pathways have instructions on which way the tokens must move. The components are of a nice quality and even comes with a cloth bag to hold the wine bottle pawns.

A customized version of Wheeler Dealer set in Gig Harbor, WA. Gig Harbor is famous for being at one end of The Narrows bridge that collapsed in a wind storm while the camera was rolling. The Narrows Bridge has been rebuilt, and Gig Harbor is now connected to Tacoma.

This edition is sponsored by the Gig Harbor Lions Club and includes a one-sheet history Gig Harbor. Not surprisingly, it does all fit on one sheet.

Dice game of American football. Features 1 kicking die; 2 offense dice (1 run; 1 pass); 2 defense dice (1 run defense; 1 pass defense). Players roll off to determine results of plays, keeping track of field position mentally or on paper. Follows rules of football.
Players roll special fairway dice and putting die to determine shot location and number of strokes for a round of golf.

JIHAD

Strategy game about the "holy war".
Each player plays a God and tries to convert countries to his beliefs. He has to win over 5 countries to his beliefs to both end and win the game.

Game Information

The aim is to build up the most money by buying or selling an intriguing range of every day items; sounds easy ? Well the twist is, that a roll of the die will mean you have to buy & sell in the value of a different year each time (ranging from 1950-1995) !

Imagine, buying a microwave oven at 1970's price (£259) & selling it in 1995 (£90) !

Not so easy eh !

Contents

100 x Goodie cards

1 x Set play money

6 x Playing pieces

1 x Regular die

1 x Year die

link.value: TV Series: The Price is Right

name.value: Jacht op Shredder Teenage Mutant Hero Turtles

item.description:
You are one of the four hero (not ninja) turtles. 12 cards are placed on the table in a 4*4 square without the corners. Each turtle starts in a different corner. You throw the dice and may move your turtle on the cards in any direction.
When you land on a card, you turn it over. If the card shows a pizza, you get a pizza-card. When you land on an opponent (Bebop, Rock Steady, Krang, Shredder), you'll have to fight him. You throw the dice, you may add pizza-points, and when you have more than indicated on the card, you win the card. 
The first to conquer the four bad guys, wins the game.

item.description: In RGB - a barbaric game played with Icehouse pieces on a chessboard - you're trying to kill your opponent's children. (You were warned it was barbaric!) You control an army of RGBs - alien creatures with three distinct layers of thought - and they lose one layer (and an ability) if they are attacked. For example, children must remain next to a piece which still has the green sustenance layer, or the child starves. Children can be created if the spare pieces exist, but only by one male and one female, both with the blue 'reproduction' layer. And attacks can only be carried out by pieces with the red destruction layer. RGB bears a few similarities to Chess, but not as many as you might think.

item.description:
Game using a 3×3 grid and Icehouse pieces to match stacks of pyramids on one of two goal cards dealt at the beginning of the game. Two ways to win, thus "Twin Win".

A simple and quick single Treehouse set game with changing goals


 Players: 2-3

 Setup time: 1 minute

item.description:
(From the publisher's website)

The Amazing Moa Hunt is a truly iconic New Zealand game. If you like treasure hunts, you’re going to love searching beautiful Aotearoa for Moa treasures (footprints & eggs) by guessing the location of New Zealand towns and cities. Experienced explorers can play a second, even more challenging game. Using a set of clue cards, you can launch a fast paced battle requiring quick thinking and even quicker answers!

* Enjoy some fun family times together for Ages 8 and up
 * 2 games in one for 2-4 players
 * Build both knowledge and memory skills
 * Perfect for both classroom and home use

(From the publisher's website)

FOURSITE™ is a game that stretches the intellect, tests your ability to multi-strategise and provides a different set of challenges every time you play it. Quick and easy to set up, it relies on a small degree of chance and a high degree of strategic thinking and ingenuity to outwit the opposition. Consisting of 74 wooden tiles, each containing four symbols, FOURSITE™ allows point scoring based on your ability to match symbols, capture territory, and create formations around a fifth symbol. A second simpler version of the game provides fun for younger players (5-8 years).

* Develops concentration skills & mathematical patterning abilities
 * Provides plenty of challenge for experienced strategy game enthusiasts
 * Attractive wooden design makes it a perfect coffee table gift
 * Ages 8 and up
 * 2 games in one for 2-4 players

 * Builds both knowledge and memory skills
 * Perfect for both classroom and home use

The iQube™ Boardgame & Puzzle is our original award winning three dimensional mind challenge, comprising of four strategic boardgames and a deceptively simple looking puzzle. It was only available for sale in Australia and New Zealand, but miQube is available from the Mindware catalog.

* Silver Honour Medal from the Parents' Choice Foundation (USA)
 * Develops mathematical concepts and spatial reasoning skills
 * Perfect for all ages and stages - Ages 7 and up

From the publisher's webpage:

Battleship Captain is a simulation game depicting ship vs ship combat in the era of the battleship. The game covers warships produced in the pre-dreadnought (1890-1906), dreadnought (1906-1919), and World War II (1920-1945) eras, providing gamers the chance to replay a virtually unlimited number of historical or hypothetical scenarios occurring during the six decade "golden age" of the battleship.
 What's Included: Over ONE THOUSAND individually rated warships (light cruiser size and larger) from over twenty of the world's navies, from the three eras represented in the game, on twenty-two counter sheets; 150 generic destroyer and merchant ship counters; 56-page comprehensive rulebook containing standard instructions applicable to each major period, plus separate chapters with "era specific" rules, Ship Rating Index, designer's notes, over thirty scenarios; scenario guidelines folder; over 300 color game markers and playing gauges; and three Reference Cards. This is a full, complete game... nothing else is needed to recreate surface combat over the entire period!
 Battleship Captain is a "miniatures" game system with scenarios played on the tabletop or floor, using the rules and ship counters provided. (You may freely substitute metal miniatures if you wish.) The game emphasized playability, as players maneuver their ships and try to defeat the enemy. The counters (measuring 2.5" x 5/8ths inch) are printed in black ink on different colored cardstock, and need to be mounted and separated prior to play. Game scale is seven turns per hour, and 1000 yards per inch. Ships are rated, right on their counter, in the following categories: name, nationality, ship type, year, flotation, stern-broadside-bow fire ratings, movement, armor, and nine "special characteristics" ratings, plus an overhead scale view of the ship's deck.

name.value: Rules of Battle: Grand Tactical Warfare During the Age of Prince Eugene of Savoy 1683-1730

item.description:
"Rules of Battle" depicts battles during the "Age of Marlborough" such as the Nine Years War, the War of Spanish Succession and the Great Northern War. The game is designed to play the large battles of the period: battles of 100,000 men can be resolved in an evening, with tables only a mere 3' x 5'. The game is designed for miniatures 15mm or smaller.

Scale: 1 inch = 500 feet. Each stand is 1000 infantry, 450 skirmishers, 600-750 cavalry or 10-15 guns. Each turn is 10-15 minutes. Standard bases are 40mm wide.

The playing board consists of 22 colored circle spots, 1 'Start' spot, and 1 'Finish' spot. These areas are connected by arrows which show players where they may move to. Then each player shakes the bottle containing 4 colored plastic balls which is tilted until one of the balls rolls out. The color revealed indicates the allowed position on the game board a player may move. Movement is required, but only if possible. The first one to get from the Start position to the Finish circle, wins.

name.value: Fantasy & Science Fiction Movie Trivia Game

item.description:
From the box:

If you love the worlds of Hobbits, Wizards or starships this is the game for you. Questions range from the early days of Dracula and Frankenstein through to Harry and Frodo.

Contains: 200 Trivia Cards, Score Pad and Instructions.

Ages 12 and up.

Description from box back:

"A fantastic toy is being sold in the toyshop and it's the only one left. You want that toy and you want to get it as fast as possible. So get your shopping carts and go, go, go for that toy!

Move your character playing piece on the stairs by moving your shopping cart playing piece around the board and landing on the shape, which is the same as the shape in front of your character playing piece and also has the same colour. Be the first to reach the toyshop to get the toy and win!

This matching game will not only develop the children's motor, and visual and observation skills but also provide them with fun and enjoyment. "

Ages 5 and up

1839, The Netherlands. The new railways are the way to get rich. Invest your money in the best railway companies. Become the President of one or more companies and lead them to become the best earning companies of the game. Build new track and stations, buy the right trains and push the stock value to new heights. Who will become the most successful investor?

Steam over Holland is an economics game in which the players invest in and control railway companies. The game is part of the 18xx family of games.

item.description:
Players try to peg out by rolling dice combinations that match the different lanes on the wooden, cribbage-like pegging board. For instance, the peg in your 6 lane moves one space closer to home with every 6 you have rolled on the dice. Once you peg out on a given lane, you now score victory points every time you roll that number. Opportunities exist to bump your opponent back by landing on him, or to have your roll count double, depending on your peg position.

But first, each time you roll the dice, you have to set aside any pair of dice that add up to seven! If the first throw doesn't look good enough, you may take one re-roll.

Diver Down is a boardgame about Scuba Diver Exploration, as well as can be done in what is known as a Eurogame. 
The game relies heavily on the use of money cards for purchasing supplies needed to dive on sites around the world. Treasures are found at each site, and if a player bids highest, they become the expedition leader and can bring up the best treasures. All other players will get some lesser treasures. Only the treasures taken by the expedition leader will be able to be taken to the museum and score points. There are three museum tracks, one for each: gold, pottery, and jewelry; worth 4,3,2 points respectively. The player with the most points after 5 rounds will be declared the winner and gain the respect of their fellow divers.

item.description:
A gripping duel between two hungry crocodiles and a bold "oarsman".

One player steers two green crocodiles, the other player owns a red rowing boat (wooden playing pieces). Both start opposite of each other in the middle of a 4 by 8 "river" board. The boat player secretly chooses one card (printed with the values 1 to 4) to select the column on the board he wishes to move to. The crocodile player has to guess this column and place his crocodiles on two spaces to block the boat. If the crocodile player was right, the boat has to retreat one row into the direction of "its" river bank, if the other player succeeded in choosing a crocodile-free space, he moves one step to the river bank of the other player.
Whoever reaches the opposite bank first is the winner.
No tactics involved, just blind guessing.

Was available as a big box with nicely designed components first, later followed by a small version (1988) with tiny pieces and (flimsy) cardboard river (with lots of air in the box).

Harry Wu's Chicago Express is an innovative new boardgame with no luck factor. Chicago Express was originally released in a limited format by Winsome Games as Wabash Cannonball and it was the first game in Winsome's Historic Railroads System.

In the game the B&O, C&O, Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads drive from the East Coast across the growing eastern US to Chicago. Smaller, more aggressive railroads like the Wabash spring up to further expand America's extensive railroads. The sharpest railroad executives vie for the maximum return on their investment in this business game lasting about one hour.

A session of Chicago Express is played over a maximum of 8 rounds. In each round, the players take turns choosing one of three available actions:
- auctioning a share of one of the railroad companies
- expanding the rail system of one of the railroad companies
- develop one of the board's hexes
Of each of those actions only a limited number is available.

As soon as all available actions of two options are taken, a dividend phase is executed, where all players gain income from the railroad companies they have shares of.
After this dividend phase, the number of actions is reset and a new round begins.

The game ends after 8 rounds or if one of the following conditions is met:
- 3 or more companies have no more locomotives
- 3 or more companies have no more shares
- The general supply contains only 3 houses or fewer

The player with the most money wins.

Once the 10 items are obtained, players must continue to the "Aisle" space and go down the aisle track to win the game.

item.description: Under the banner of "Our Town Trivia", then this version has the almost similar layout as with what you would have for the 'trivia' genre. Unlike some others with the closely related naming sort, then those have their depiction of another nearby region superimposed upon a "M~onopoly" 'clone'. They've taken another approach for it all here, with such as including one DECK of the 'Trivia' cards that has locally generated information of people, places, or events that many another from beyond its setting might not be too familiar with as well. The *Spaces* have all manner of locales that were around at the time that it was produced, while since many have now long gone "out of business"!
This is a area impulse movement wargame using a modified Storm Over Arnhem/Storm Over Stalingrad system to simulate the Battle of Leyte Gulf 1944.

Dugout Dreams is a baseball simulation that used one 20-sided die and two 10-sided dice. The game comes with 17 pitching charts on 5 pages, a color playing field on which to keep track of outs and base runners, score sheets, and various charts, including: fly outs, hit & run, hitting direction for left- and right-handed batters, runner advancement, ground outs, hold/steal, errors, and steals. Teams are available from various seasons, including some recent ones and 1926, 1948, and 1971. Players' ratings are listed on 8.5 x 11" card stock, one page for each team. (There are no individual cards in this game.) Ratings are based on actual performance from these respective seasons.

To play, roll a d20 and cross-reference the result with the Batting Rating on Player's Batting listing with that of the Pitcher's Chart, where the following results are found: blank (an out), W (a possible walk), or H (a hit). Each of these results requires an additional 2-4 rolls of two d10 dice to resolve a given play.

Pitchers are rated for Start/Relief effectiveness, walks, strike outs, home runs yielded, ground balls, fly balls, stamina, hold ability, and fielding.

Batters are rated in the following categories: Batting, HR, 1B, 2B, 3B, W, K, Fielding, Range/Arm, SAC, BS (base stealing) and BR (base running).

name.value: NI-SHI-KI: The Sliding Samurai Card Chess

item.description:
NI-SHI-KI (two-four-chess) is the chess-like board game, using cards as chessmen, and featuring wars of warring states in Medieval Japan.

Cards representing Units (like spearmen or bowmen) and Warlords (like Oda Nobunaga or Uesugi Kenshin) are put on the sliding plates. Plates with cards are ready to slide over surface of the game board to attack the enemy cards or enemy castle. Each battle is resolved by comparing sum of strength of each cards and a die roll.

Mixture of Dynamism (of sliding plate movement) and Luck (with rolling dice which may overturn situation) made good strategy and playability in this game.

'Home Page: http://www.c-no.cc/nishiki.html (Japanese)

item.description: One of six great demon lords is slowly awakening from deep slumber, and if he does, there will be hell on Earth. It might be Cthulhu, or Shub-Niggurath, but most players won't know the identity of the hidden card until the endgame. This is important because each of the six tomes is best against a specific demon lord, middling against most of the others, and worthless against another specific one. Players are different teams of adventurers in the 1920s, finding tomes like the Necronomicon, fighting monsters like the Mi-Go, and solving world-spanning Events, mysteries of Lovecraftian weirdness. Events give victory points to whoever finally solves them, but the great demon will arise if there are 100 points worth of these Events in the unsolved stack--if he arises, there is the endgame of final apocalyptic battle. So players are constantly balancing co-operation with competition--under certain circumstances, a player can discover the great demon ahead of the endgame, and even decide to join the demon!

item.description:
Players take on the roles of FBI agents trying to capture mobsters, getting them off the street and into the federal penitentiary.

Agents roll the dice and move around the board. If they land on a mobster space, the mobster card is transferred to their penitentiary. In addition, if the mobster had not been previously captured, you claim the reward money listed on the mobster card. You can also nab mobsters by playing Capture cards from your hand. Play continues until all mobsters have been jailed. The agent with the most mobsters in the pen wins.

Contains:
1 game board
2 dice
1 deck of 36 cards
6 player packets
6 agent playing pawns
36 mobster cards
18 capture cards
6 cards numbered 1 through 6
Treasury chips in three denominations.

This game has players competing to build up their Mr. Potato Head Pal (the "pals" are 4 different smaller-sized Mr. Potato Head figures--two boys and two girls, each with different hats, eyes, mouths, etc). The game can be played in two ways--in the more difficult version, players compete to complete the specific "pal" they have a card for. In the slightly easier variation, players compete to build any kind of pal first, similar to Cootie.
Dexterity game in which the 2 players try and tip the board to roll the bugs towards the other player.

A roll and move racing game that feature TV cartoon characters on roller skates.

Features characters from the TV show "The Skatebirds" including Moe, Larry and Curly; The Three Robotic Stooges.

Object: Be the first player to reach the Treehouse Studio.

From the box: The zany Skatebirds scurry around trying to organize their TV show. ScatCat does all that he can to foul up the Skatebirds plans. He has built a marble slide at the Treehouse and does his best to stop the Skateboard.

name.value: First Learning Games: Things that go

item.description: 23 learning games for young children. Featuring characters from Walt Disney cartoons in cars, trucks, balloons and other "things that move".

Roll and Move children's outer space game for 2,3, or 4 players. Dated 1968 and numbered #4931, this game is in nice condition. This game is based on the 1966 movie "Fantastic Voyage", starring Steven Boyd and Raquel Welch.
Based on the cartoon series loosely based on concept of the movie.
Spin and move children's game based on Walt Disney's Peter Pan

The king of Utopia has invited princes of the greatest civilizations of antiquity to come and live within the walls of his city, welcoming in doing so, the architectural wealth of their far-away cities. As the King’s Minister, your Sovereign has given you the mission to welcome and accompany these princes and princesses who will present themselves at the gates of the city. Every development added to the city made by your guests increases your prestige.

Online play


 Jeux sur un Plateau (turn-based)


Components:
40 Monument Figures: 8 for each of the 5 civilizations (Mayan, Persian, Egyptian, Greek and Chinese)
4 Wonder Figures
5 Minister Figures: 1 of each color (used for Score Track)
200 Prince Tokens: 40 of each color
40 Bases
10 Privilege tokens: 8 of each color. 2 per color
40 Guest tokens: 2 per civilization for each of the four islands on the board
50 Action Cards: 10 for each civilization
5 Rule Summary Cards: 1 per player
1 Bag

Basic Game play:

Turn order (after the first player) is derived from who has the highest score on the perimtere score track yet has not had a turn. Each game turn is broken down into three phases:
Phase 1: Welcoming the Princes
Phase 2: Development of the City
Phase 3: Calculation of Prestige Points

Phase 1: Welcoming the Princes

In the first phase, Guest tokens are placed on the board near ship icons but corresponding to the symbol on each token. These guest tokens are then replaced with Prince tokens that is their own color, or of the same civilization as the chosen Guest or in any District of the island indicated by the Guest or any combination of these. This is repeated three times until all Guest tokens have been removed from the board. While this is happening, players may Build a Wonder or Take Control of a District.

At any point during their turn, if a player has one prince of each of the 5 civilizations on one island (regardless of which Districts they are in), he may immediately construct a Wonder and receives 6 Prestige Points. There may only be one Wonder per island and a player does not have to construct Wonders.

At any point during their turn, if a player possesses 3 princes of the same civilization in the same District, and that District is not already controlled by another player, he may decide to take control of the District by placing a Monument on that District. There can only be one Monument per District, and this space, once acquired, cannot be retaken. For taking control of a District the player gains Prestige Points during Phase 3: Calculation of Prestige Points. Also, if the District belongs to an island where a Wonder has been constructed, the owner of the Wonder immediately scores the number of Prestige Points indicated on the District.

Phase 2: Development of the City

Each player receives 5 Action cards and discards based on their score in the score track. The person in the lead discards two cards, the last player doesn't discard any and all other players discard one. Four types of actions are possible and occur multiple times in a player's turn:

1) Move one or two princes:

If a player decides to move two princes with a single action card, these two princes must be within the same District and make the same movement.

LAND MOVEMENT: By discarding an action card, a player may move one or two princes of that civilization to an adjacent District (Districts are separated by alleys or bridges).

SEA MOVEMENT: By discarding an action card, a player may move one or two princes of that civilization from one maritime District (showing a ship) to another maritime District. These two Districts must be in the same maritime sector or in two adjacent maritime sectors. (The division of the maritime sectors is indicated by the dotted lines originating from the 3 lighthouses of the city).

2) Add a prince:

By discarding an Action Card, a player may place a prince in a District occupied by a Monument of that civilization.

3) Remove a Prince:

If the player possesses a prince in a District occupied by a Monument of that civilization, regardless of the player who controls the District, that player may, with an Action Card of that civilization, remove the Prince from the board. For this action the player immediately gains 2 Prestige Points. Th e player’s Minister figure is moved up two places on the Score Track.

or 4) Influence the King (altering the Prestige Scale):

If the player possesses a prince in a District occupied by a Monument of that civilization, regardless of the player who controls the District, that player may, with an Action Card of that civilization, remove the Prince from the board. For this action the player immediately gains 2 Prestige Points. The player’s Minister figure is moved up two places on the Score Track.

The value of each civilization, indicated on the Prestige Scale, determines the point value of the districts controlled by each player at the end of the turn. By discarding an Action Card, a player may increase the value of a civilization by 1. The Value figure of the civilization changes places with the figure directly above it. With two Action cards, a player may reduce the value of a civilization to 1. All the other figures are moved up accordingly. At the end of their turn a player can only have a maximum of 5 Action Cards.

Phase 3: Calculation of Prestige Points

Once all the players have carried out their actions, the points for the round are calculated. Each player, in turn order, gains points for each District that they control. The value of each civilization is indicated on the Prestige Scale. The players’ Minister figures are moved up the Score Track.

If one or more players have reached at least 50 Prestige Points at the end of this phase, the game ends. The player with the most points wins.

item.description:
Trivia game with a wind up clock that displays the questions and answers from a "player piano" type roll.

Features 3 categories. US Presidents, Countries of the World and Domesticated Animals.

Players fight strange monsters in two worlds--the real world and the dream world--with different strengths in each place. This game has several two-sided location cards, where one side shows the real world version and the other side shows the dream world version. These locations are the battlegrounds, against monsters like the Wandering Stuffed Toy. Special cards use dream imagery, like Psycho Slip (doorways hovering in space), Escape (from monster), and Corridor of a Dream (running on a moebius strip).

There are 34 cards in denominations from 1 to 10, as well with 2 instructions kinds for the couple of variations with this. Avoid the Shark!

item.description:
This game is a rummy style collecting game based upon the underground [subway] railway [railroad] stations of London, England. From names of stations and fact that Thomas De La Rue, address as given on my pack is given as 110 Bunhill Row, London EC1, which was destroyed by bombs during WW2,this game dates from 1930s. The pack consists of 72 cards - 50 unique station cards which have small photograph of area around station, 16 junction cards i.e. EARL'S COURT, BANK & MONUMENT, HOLBORN [x2], KING'S CROSS, OXFORD CIRCUS, TOTTENHAM COURT ROAD, LEICESTER SQUARE [x2], PICADILLY [x2], BAKER STREET and CHARING CROSS [x4]. and 6 exactly the same Season Tickets [which act as jokers for interchange cards.]
The Object of the game is go LOBO by making up a hand of two or more completed journeys either exposed or unexposed. A completed journey consists of a junction card together with two station cards. On the junction card are printed the names of starting or finishing stations made through that particular junction.
Although rules state that game can be played by any number there is a limit to number of players which is constrained by the size of the pack which I suggest is 6 at most.

name.value: The Titans of Terror vs. The Forces of Good

item.description:
If you would dare to experience a maelstrom of miniature mayhem, then enter the world of "The Titans of Terror vs. The Forces of Good", Ral Partha's first installment in a throat-clutching trilogy of horror. This foray into the fantastic has been created exclusively for Sculptor's Row by one of the world's top fantasy sculptors, Dennis Mize.

An avid collector of classic monster movies, Dennis Mize has designed the "Titans" to capture the look and feel of the classic Fantasy and Sci-Fi films of the 50's and 60's. The "Titans" are presented in a "serial" format, so that each new boxed set will contain the latest "episode". These scenarios, when combined, will reveal the complete and mesmerizing tale of "The Titans of Terror".

The Ultimate MindTrap - the Challenge Continues is an incomparable collection of 300 all new murder mysteries, brainteasers, trick questions & visual experiences that will capture your imagination & challenge the way you think... and see !

In the twisted world of MindTrap, your team will encounter a variety of challenging categories. You will confront the classic mystery scenario that is richly illustrated & riddled with both clues & red herrings. Then you'll find yourself racing the opposing team in shaping a Tangram teaser or assembling a beguiling matchstick puzzler. Or for a completely different twist, stretch your imagination to identify a magnified photograph of a common object that you know you know, and yet, it hovers there, defiantly out of reach. All the MindTrap questions are written in humorous prose with a delightful twist that will make you laugh at the surprisingly simple solutions.

In MindTrap, it's not what you know that counts... it's how you think !

The Introductory Box Set is designed as the entry point into the game for new BattleTech players. The quick-start rules, which can be learned in under an hour, will have new players quickly slugging it out in the thirty-foot-tall war machines known as BattleMechs. The longer introductory rules provide more extensive guidelines for 'Mech movement and combat as well as construction rules for building or customizing your own (introductory-level) 'Mechs. Quick-start rules for vehicles and infantry are also included for players interested in combined-arms battles. Also included in the box set is a BattleTech universe book providing an overview of the game world, its history, and its factions. A set of 2 unpainted plastic 'Mechs, ready for play and suitable for painting, are accompanied by prefilled record sheets listing each 'Mech's capabilities. The set also includes maps, a painting and tactics guide, cardstock reference sheets, a universe poster map of the BattleTech universe, and two six-sided dice.

The 2011 "Twenty-Fifth Anniversary Edition" of the box set replaces the 2007 edition's thin paper maps with board game-style mounted maps, adds two "high-quality" plastic minis (a Thor and a Loki (and accompanying record sheets), and includes a brief guide detailing the BattleTech gaming system intended to introduce new players to the various products for the game.

Expanded by:
Other introductory-level products:

 Classic Battletech Starterbook: Sword and Dragon (Scenario book and sourcebook designed as a bridge between the box set and Total Warfare)
 Classic Battletech: Technical Readout â€“ 3039 (Companion "technical readout," with game "fluff" and unit statistics)
 Classic Battletech: Record Sheets â€“ 3039 (Print version of selected prefilled record sheets for TRO: 3039; also includes two scenarios and additional rules)
 Battletech Hexpack: Lakes and Rivers (Additional maps and terrain overlays to add more variety to gameplay)




Intermediate-/standard-level products:

 Battletech: Total Warfare (Full standard/tournament rules for BattleTech)
 Classic Battletech: TechManual (Full construction rules for BattleTech units)
 Classic Battletech: Technical Readout â€“ 3050 Upgrade (Technical readout for the early Clan invasion period)
 Battletech: Record Sheets: 3050 Upgrade (Print version of selected prefilled record sheets for TRO: 3050U; also includes two scenarios and additional rules)
